00001 
00005 #include <iostream>
00006 
00007 using namespace std;
00008 
00010 class AbstractClass
00011 {
00012 public:
00013   //demanding polymorphic capability
00014   virtual void print() = 0;
00015 };
00016 
00018 class BaseClass : public AbstractClass
00019 {
00020 public:
00021   //allowing polymorphic behavior from derived classes
00022   //the virtual keyword is superfluious here
00023   virtual void print()
00024   { std::cout << "base class" << std::endl; }
00025 };
00026 
00028 class ChildClass : public BaseClass
00029 {
00030 public:
00031   //taking advantage of polymorphism by overriding parrent function
00032   void print()
00033   { std::cout << "child class" << std::endl; }
00034 };
00035 
00037 class AnotherChildClass : public BaseClass
00038 {
00039 public:
00040   //do NOT take advantage of polymorphism
00041   //void print()
00042   //{ std::cout << "child class" << std::endl; }
00043 };
00044 
00046 void callPrint(AbstractClass& p)
00047 {
00048   //call the appropriat function (based on the actual type of
00049   //BaseClass -be it derived or not)
00050   p.print();
00051 }
00052 
00054 int main(int argc, char **argv)
00055 {
00056   BaseClass b;
00057   ChildClass c;
00058   AnotherChildClass a;
00059 
00060   //concrete behavior
00061   callPrint(b);
00062 
00063   //polymorphic behavior
00064   callPrint(c);
00065 
00066   //concrete (hiarchial) behavior
00067   callPrint(a);
00068 }
